channel.title: Anglotopia.net
channel.description: The Website for People Who Love Britain - Anglophiles

item.title: Unwrapping Boxing Day: 10 Fascinating Facts and Figures about this British Tradition
item.dc:creator: Jonathan
item.description:
Boxing Day, observed on the day after Christmas, has long been a cherished tradition in Britain. Steeped in history and laden with unique customs, this day holds a special place in the hearts of many Brits. In this article, we delve into 10 interesting facts and figures that shed light on the significance and peculiarities […]

The post Unwrapping Boxing Day: 10 Fascinating Facts and Figures about this British Tradition appeared first on Anglotopia.net.

item.title: The King’s 2023 Official Christmas Message – Full Video
item.dc:creator: Jonathan
item.description:
As is our tradition here at Anglotopia, here is the King’s 2023 Christmas message in full. King Charles spoke of faith, fellowship, and compassion in his second Christmas message. He thanked the “selfless army” of volunteers who he said were the “backbone” of British society, even on Christmas day. Happy Christmas, everyone! Here is the […]

The post The King’s 2023 Official Christmas Message – Full Video appeared first on Anglotopia.net.

item.title: One Anglophile’s Take on The Lion in Winter
item.dc:creator: Derek
item.description:
As I write this, it’s December, only a few days until Christmas. And for the past couple weeks, I’ve been watching quite a few Christmas movies. Not the sort of cookie-cutter movies Hallmark and other companies keep churning out. I’m talking legitimately good movies that just happened to fall on Christmas. One movie I found […]

The post One Anglophile’s Take on The Lion in Winter appeared first on Anglotopia.net.

item.title: Tickets on sale for Pop-Up hotels at Glastonbury
item.dc:creator: Derek
item.description:
In 2011, Glastonbury set up a “Pop-Up Hotel” for the first time. On 14 December 2023, I heard about it for the first time. Quoth the Pop-Up Hotel’s website, “For those who enjoy the freedom that comes with camping, but don’t want to compromise when it comes to their home comforts, glamping is the perfect […]

The post Tickets on sale for Pop-Up hotels at Glastonbury appeared first on Anglotopia.net.

item.title: Royal 101: Royal Country Homes
item.dc:creator: John Rabon
item.description:
While many homes inhabited by the Royal Family are actually the property of the Crown, there are residences within the family’s portfolio that are their private property.  The castles and palaces don’t fall into this category, but plenty of country estates do.  These country homes include some pretty well-known estates that have been in the […]

The post Royal 101:  Royal Country Homes appeared first on Anglotopia.net.

item.title: New research shows the most beautiful bus routes in Britain
item.dc:creator: Anglotopia Staff
item.description:
A new study has revealed the top 10 most scenic bus routes in the UK. The study, conducted by over 50s experts SunLife, analyzed over 40 different bus routes throughout the country, based on Instagram hashtags. So, if you’re looking for some inspiration for your next trip, keep reading to discover the most picturesque bus […]

The post New research shows the most beautiful bus routes in Britain appeared first on Anglotopia.net.

item.title: The Fiver – Five British Actors in DC and Marvel Films
item.dc:creator: John Rabon
item.description:
There’s a lot of hay made about the rivalry between DC Comics and Marvel Comics’ film adaptations, but over the decades since 1978’s Superman and 1986’s Howard the Duck (yes, it is technically the first Marvel movie), plenty of actors have crossed over from one universe to the other.  From heroes to villains and vice-versa, […]

item.title: A Fairytale of New York: The Story of the Least Likely Holiday Hit
item.dc:creator: Derek
item.description:
On 30 November 2023, Shane MacGowan, lead singer of Punk group The Pogues, died of pneumonia. As a longtime Pogues fan, I decided I should find a way to pay homage. Perhaps I should write a whole biography for him here. But then, December hit. I remembered “Fairy Tale of New York.” I thought, maybe […]

item.title: 10 Cozy British Christmas Traditions
item.dc:creator: Jonathan
item.description:
Christmas is a time of festivity, joy, and happiness for people all around the world. Every country has its own unique set of traditions and customs that make the holiday season special. In the United Kingdom, Christmas is celebrated with a variety of traditions that reflect the country’s rich history and culture. From the iconic […]

The post 10 Cozy British Christmas Traditions appeared first on Anglotopia.net.

item.title: The Fiver – Five Famous Brits You Didn’t Know Were in Star Wars
item.dc:creator: John Rabon
item.description:
For every Han, Luke, and Leia, whose faces grace the silver screen across multiple films, there are plenty of actors who play their parts without us knowing who they really are.  Whether covered in alien makeup, wearing helmets, or CGI’d into something entirely not human, these actors deliver no less memorable roles.  In fact, you […]

The post The Fiver – Five Famous Brits You Didn’t Know Were in Star Wars appeared first on Anglotopia.net.

item.title: Book Excerpt: End to End – A History of Travels Around Britain
item.dc:creator: Jonathan
item.category: Anglotopia's Grand Adventure - Land's End to John O'Groats
item.description:
First, thank you to everyone who has bought a copy of my new book End to End: Britain From Land’s End to John o’Groats so far! It’s always rewarding for something you’ve worked for so long on to start to be enjoyed by people. Over the next few weeks, I will share a few excerpts […]

item.title: New Book: End to End – Britain From Land’s End to John o’Groats – A Travel Memoir
item.dc:creator: Jonathan
item.category: Anglotopia's Grand Adventure - Land's End to John O'Groats
item.description:
Finally, after years of writing and refining, I’m excited to announce that my latest book, End to End: Britain From Land’s End to John o’Groats, is now available for sale from us and from booksellers everywhere. It’s a travel memoir exploring Britain from Cornwall all the way to Scotland. It’s available to order today directly […]

item.title: David Gilmour and The Orb launch an AI remixing site
item.dc:creator: Derek
item.description:
In 2008, Pink Floyd’s David Gilmour released a cover of, of all songs, Graham Nash’s “Chicago.” After recording it, he reached out to English Ambient Techno group The Orb. They agreed on the condition that he re-record some guitar parts for them. This turned into an entire album of its own: Metallic Spheres. Over a […]

The post David Gilmour and The Orb launch an AI remixing site appeared first on Anglotopia.net.

item.title: Britain’s Top Ten Heritage and Steam Railways
item.dc:creator: John Rabon
item.description:
The preservation of the past should always be a top priority since it helps us understand how those who came before us live.  Heritage railways are a part of this since they help keep a link to Britain’s transportation history.  At one point, heritage railways were a primary means of moving goods and people, but […]

The post Britain’s Top Ten Heritage and Steam Railways appeared first on Anglotopia.net.

item.title: Ten Interesting Facts about The Pet Shop Boys
item.dc:creator: John Rabon
item.description:
Formed by Neil Tennant and Chris Lowe in 1981, the synth-pop duo have been international stars with hits like “West End Girls,” “Heart,” “It’s a Sin,” “Opportunities (Let’s Make Lots of Money),” and “Always on My Mind.”  Most of their chart-topping hits came out in the 1980s and they were associated with the “Second British […]

The post Ten Interesting Facts about The Pet Shop Boys appeared first on Anglotopia.net.

item.title: Ten Types of British Cheese
item.dc:creator: John Rabon
item.description:
As much as tea and beer, one of the most prominent food exports in the United Kingdom is cheese.  Cheese is as much a cultural icon in Britain as anything and there are over 700 different kinds of cheese made throughout the country.  Each region tends to have its own variety and whether it’s a […]

The post Ten Types of British Cheese appeared first on Anglotopia.net.

item.title: Olivia Harrison gives her story for “Now and Then.”
item.dc:creator: Derek
item.description:
If you bought the 7″ single for the Beatles’ “Now and Then,” you probably noticed the back cover. It featured a strange-looking clock, one that seems to have been made out of a bunch of spare items that just happened to be lying around. As I trawled through the Beatles’ subreddit, it seemed that, while […]

item.title: The Fiver – Five British Dystopias
item.dc:creator: John Rabon
item.description:
By its nature, satire is a form of storytelling that is used to take a critical lens to the ills of a society, organization, government, or individual. Dystopias depict a future that has gone wrong. More often than not, these two walk hand-in-hand, creating a world that serves as a warning to us today. Dystopian […]

The post The Fiver – Five British Dystopias appeared first on Anglotopia.net.

item.title: Ten Interesting Facts about the Film Willow
item.dc:creator: John Rabon
item.description:
Having succeeded in science-fiction and supernatural adventure, in 1988 Lucasfilm turned its attention to fantasy.  The film Willow featured the titular protagonist saddled with the responsibility of protecting a baby that was destined to bring down an evil queen.  Starring a relatively unknown Warwick Davis in his first leading role along with Val Kilmer, Joanne […]

The post Ten Interesting Facts about the Film Willow appeared first on Anglotopia.net.

item.title: The Fiver: Five British Films Featured on Mystery Science Theater 3000
item.dc:creator: John Rabon
item.description:
In the not-too-distant future…well, the distant past really.  Back in 1988, a little show starring prop comedian Joel Hodgson debuted on a small Minnesota station.  It had a simple premise of a man stuck on a space station with his two robot friends, forced to watch bad movies by a pair of mad scientists.  In […]

item.title: Bowie’s Snowman scarf now for sale
item.dc:creator: Derek
item.description:
A few years ago, I wrote a big article about The Snowman. One of the many bases I covered was this little intro David Bowie made for the few times it aired in America. At least it still airs on Channel 4 more often than not. Bowie played a grown-up version of the boy from […]

item.title: The man on the Led Zeppelin IV cover identified

item.description:

That said, having the album art at hand will be important. The cover art for Led Zeppelin’s fourth album is one of the most notorious […]

item.title: Royal History: Uncrowned Monarchs
item.dc:creator: John Rabon
item.description:
Ever since the crowning of King William I in Westminster Abbey in 1066, the coronation of the British monarch has been a major affair for the United Kingdom.  However, this grand ceremony has not been enjoyed by every individual to call themselves king or queen, and several never made it to this point.  The reigns […]

The post Royal History: Uncrowned Monarchs appeared first on Anglotopia.net.

item.title: Ten British Actors with Great American Accents
item.dc:creator: John Rabon
item.description:
Acting often requires taking on roles very different from one’s own personality and upbringing, which also sometimes requires taking on accents from completely different parts of the world.  Some actors are quite good at this, while others are not so much.  With plenty of movies and television shows filming in Atlanta and Los Angeles, actors […]

item.title: The Beatles release “Now and Then,” their final song
item.dc:creator: Derek
item.description:
It’s official. The Beatles are back, even if it’s only for a few minutes. Last week, I wrote about how the Beatles were going to release one more song, and now it’s here. And how is it? It’s not great, but that’s mostly because, well, the band’s already set a high standard for themselves. But […]

item.title: Ten Interesting Facts about Peter Cushing
item.dc:creator: John Rabon
item.description:
Perhaps one of the most underrated actors of the 20th Century, Peter Cushing is mostly regarded for his role as Grand Moff Tarkin in Star Wars: A New Hope.  However, to horror fans, he is an absolute legend for playing Abraham Van Helsing and Victor Frankenstein in several Hammer Studios movies from the 1950s to […]

The post Ten Interesting Facts about Peter Cushing appeared first on Anglotopia.net.

item.title: The Fiver: Five Famous British Explorers
item.dc:creator: John Rabon
item.description:
Seeing the world can be a dangerous business—especially when it hasn’t been done before.  Explorers from many countries and peoples have dared to take that first step beyond their known world to see what else is out there.  Britain is no different in this regard, having begun to seek out new places along with most […]

The post The Fiver:  Five Famous British Explorers appeared first on Anglotopia.net.

item.dc:creator: Jonathan
item.description:
As the holidays approach, we have a special offer for Anglotopia followers. We still need to clear out our Union Jack Lights from our basement warehouse. item.description:

If you would like this series to continue, please subscribe to Anglotopia’s newsletter or leave a comment telling us […]

item.title: Royal 101: The Honours Process from Nomination to Knighthood
item.dc:creator: John Rabon
item.description:
It is a dream for many Brits to one day be called “Sir” or “Dame” when they receive a knighthood from the Sovereign.  In the past, we have covered the various orders of chivalry that make up the honors but have not covered the process from beginning to end.  Even the process can have many […]

We have a new contest for Anglotopians. This massive book is almost 400 pages long […]

item.title: The Beatles announce the release of their final song
item.dc:creator: Derek
item.description:
In 1994, around the release of The Beatles Anthology, the surviving members of the Fab Four decided to get together and finish a few demos that John left behind. They planned to finish three, but they only finished two. They managed to complete “Free as a Bird” and “Real Love,” but one demo was just […]

item.title: Great British Telly: A History of Fawlty Towers
item.dc:creator: Jonathan
item.description:
Ludicrous as he often appeared, creator John Cleese always claimed that his character Basil Fawlty, the lead character in Fawlty Towers, was an accurate, if exaggerated, depiction of a real person he had encountered managing a hotel. Embodying everyone’s fears of the ‘holiday from hell,’ viewers watched in rapt attention as one disaster after another […]

item.title: Unveiling the Mystery: 10 Most Allegedly Haunted Places in Britain
item.dc:creator: Jonathan
item.description:
Britain, with its rich history and ancient architecture, has long been shrouded in tales of the supernatural. From eerie castles to abandoned asylums, the land is dotted with allegedly haunted places that have captured the imagination of locals and tourists alike. In this post, we will embark on a chilling journey through the ten most […]

The post Unveiling the Mystery: 10 Most Allegedly Haunted Places in Britain appeared first on Anglotopia.net.

item.title: The Fiver – Five British Things You Can Find in the United States
item.dc:creator: John Rabon
item.description:
While travel to the UK for pleasure might still be a ways off, there are plenty of things from Britain right here in the United States.  By this, I’m not talking about the international foods aisle of your grocery store or your local pub, but places and items whose origins were across the pond before […]

The post The Fiver – Five British Things You Can Find in the United States appeared first on Anglotopia.net.

item.title: A Brief History of British Political Cartoons
item.dc:creator: John Rabon
item.description:
While using images to tell a story dates back to cave paintings and later on to the Greeks, Romans, Egyptians, and other cultures, political cartoons or comics as we know them are a tool of satire that’s only a few hundred years old.  While the art of cartooning and caricature began in Renaissance Italy, historically, […]

item.title: Peter Gabriel announces “I/O” release date
item.dc:creator: Derek
item.description:
In 2002, Peter Gabriel released Up, his seventh solo album. Shortly after that, he announced he had enough rejected ideas for songs to make up a whole new album. That album was to be called I/O and its release date was supposed to be sometime in 2004. But 2004 came and went with no I/O. […]

item.title: Great British Telly: A History of Blackadder – Where History Became a Hilarious Joke
item.dc:creator: Jonathan
item.description:
While many consider history a joke, it is rarely a source of television comedy. Blackadder stands out for taking history – or at least an alternative version of it – and creating outstanding humor. Starring Rowan Atkinson and Tony Robinson, the show follows one person and their eponymous descendants for 400 years, re-writing major historical […]

The post Great British Telly: A History of Blackadder – Where History Became a Hilarious Joke appeared first on Anglotopia.net.

item.title: Securing the Battlements: The Loss and Preservation of Historic Castles
item.dc:creator: John Rabon
item.description:
Once upon a time, many a castle stretched towards the heavens across the United Kingdom.  Whether constructed for defense or to show off the wealth of the local lord, they were magnificent structures that represented the power of the nobility.  However, over time, many of these castles have fallen into disrepair as they were abandoned […]

The post Securing the Battlements:  The Loss and Preservation of Historic Castles appeared first on Anglotopia.net.

item.title: Ten Interesting Facts about Sir Alec Guinness
item.dc:creator: John Rabon
item.description:
Con Man, Spymaster, and Jedi Sir Alec Guinness took on many unforgettable roles over his career as an actor.  Guinness made a name for himself early in his acting career by starring in several Ealing Studios comedy films and showed what a dramatic powerhouse he could be in 1956’s The Bridge Over the River Kwai.  […]

item.dc:creator: Derek
item.description:
In a recent episode of Paul McCartney: A Life in Lyrics, Macca talked about the origins of one of the band’s last big hits. One would think there wouldn’t be much left to talk about the Get Back sessions after the documentary. Turns out there is, but it’s worth noting that the story of “Let […]

item.dc:creator: Jonathan
item.description:
Television shows about doctors are many, and they come and go in waves of popularity. But doctors are not the only ones who care for living creatures, so a show about a veterinarian doesn’t seem too much of a leap – yet such shows are rare. All Creatures Great and Small filled that niche, setting […]

item.title: Brit History: Ten Most Important British Events of the 1990s – The Cool Britannia Years
item.dc:creator: John Rabon
item.description:
The 1990s were a time of “new” in Britain.  New conflicts, new travel options, new government, a new peace, and even a new millennium helped mark the years from 1991 to 2000.  For many, the 90s were certainly a golden time for Britain at home and abroad, and the changes helped bring a better quality […]

The post Brit History: Ten Most Important British Events of the 1990s – The Cool Britannia Years appeared first on Anglotopia.net.

item.title: The Fiver: Five British Halloween Costume Ideas
item.dc:creator: John Rabon
item.description:
It’s spooky time again, and this time, we can actually go out and about to celebrate.  Of course, the best thing about Halloween is getting to dress up for parties, pub crawls, or receiving trick-or-treaters at the door.  As usual, we like to think about the fancy dress possibilities and offer up some suggestions if […]

item.dc:creator: Jonathan
item.description:
I originally put this together for those who follow the Anglotopia Twitter account, but it seemed like a good idea to publish it here as well. There are big changes in the social media world, and we’re trying to adapt to them. Our focus will always be the Anglotopia and Londontopia websites, but we try […]

item.title: Paul McCartney dissects “Eleanor Rigby” in new podcast
item.dc:creator: Derek
item.description:
Of all the songs the Beatles released between Rubber Soul and Sgt. Pepper, “Eleanor Rigby” was one of the most radical signs of a sea change in their music. From 1962 to late 1965, you knew what to expect from the Beatles. You expected some sort of mainstream pop song, something about love between “Me” […]

item.title: Great British Telly: Monty Python’s Flying Circus
item.dc:creator: Jonathan
item.description:
Monty Python’s Flying Circus burst onto staid BBC television in 1969, bringing the social satire and modern surrealism of the 60s counterculture to a wide audience. Its crazy sketches and recurring characters mocked everything British, from class behavior to attitudes toward foreigners, leaving no group untouched. Recurrent characters introduced expressions like ‘Spam’ to popular speech. […]

The post Great British Telly: Monty Python’s Flying Circus appeared first on Anglotopia.net.

item.title: The Fiver – Five Fictional Football (aka Soccer) Shows
item.dc:creator: John Rabon
item.description:
Football is the top game in the United Kingdom; after all, the island nation invented the sport.  Ever since 1863, when the modern rules were established, football has produced some dramatic moments the equal of anything in fiction.  Of course, such drama eventually found its way to the small screen with shows that went beyond […]

The post The Fiver – Five Fictional Football (aka Soccer) Shows appeared first on Anglotopia.net.

item.title: Ten Interesting Facts about Emma Thompson
item.dc:creator: John Rabon
item.description:
Whether you know her as a regular in Richard Curtis films, her classics roles, or more off-the-wall characters, chances are good that you have seen a film starring Emma Thompson.  Thompson has had a long and illustrious career in comedy and drama that started as a member of the Cambridge Footlights alongside such notable actors […]

item.dc:creator: Derek
item.description:
The Rolling Stones had a lot of potentially interesting choices for a second single from their new album Hackney Diamonds. Even when all we know beforehand is the personnel, there’s so much to choose from. “Live by the Sword,” which features the classic 1976-1991 lineup in the studio for one last time? “Bite My Head […]

item.title: Great British Telly: Yes, Minister & Yes, Prime Minister
item.dc:creator: Jonathan
item.description:
In the 1980s, Britain lived through a political revolution that became the legacy of the Prime Minister of the time, Margaret Thatcher. The response from television was to create a satirical comedy show that highlighted the venality of politicians and the elitist and obstructive behavior of the civil servants who resisted their agendas. It was […]

The post Great British Telly: Yes, Minister & Yes, Prime Minister appeared first on Anglotopia.net.

item.title: The History Fiver – Five Rebellions in British History
item.dc:creator: John Rabon
item.description:
It’s a hard thing being in charge.  You do one little thing (or maybe a lot of things) people don’t like, and suddenly, they’re up in arms against you.  Rebellions are defined as violent uprisings against the lawful authority, and in British history since the Conquest, rebellions have occurred for reasons from occupation to people’s […]

The post The History Fiver – Five Rebellions in British History appeared first on Anglotopia.net.

item.title: Ten Interesting Facts about King Edward VIII
item.dc:creator: John Rabon
item.description:
Known first and foremost for abdicating the throne to marry his love, Wallis Simpson, King Edward VIII had one of the most notorious reigns of the last two hundred years for that reason.  He also had one of the shortest reigns in British history because of it, lasting for nearly 11 months before he handed […]

The post Ten Interesting Facts about King Edward VIII appeared first on Anglotopia.net.

item.title: The Fiver – Five Unusual British Races
item.dc:creator: John Rabon
item.description:
When warmer weather hits, you can bet that race season is on.  5Ks, 10Ks, Half-Marathon, and full-Marathon races go on all over the world.  The UK has several notable races of its own, including the famous London Marathon.  There are also some pretty lesser-known, though infinitely more fascinating, races that take place across the country.  […]

The post The Fiver – Five Unusual British Races appeared first on Anglotopia.net.

item.title: Great British Telly: Dad’s Army – A World War II Comedy Classic
item.dc:creator: Jonathan
item.description:
The Home Guard always had something a little absurd about it. Made up mostly of men too old or unfit to serve in the regular armed forces, it trained with inadequate equipment for an invasion that never happened. It was only a matter of time before it became comedy material, and Dad’s Army was the […]

The post Great British Telly: Dad’s Army – A World War II Comedy Classic appeared first on Anglotopia.net.

item.title: British Slang: British Home Improvement Words and Phrases
item.dc:creator: John Rabon
item.description:
Between the United States and the United Kingdom, the words and phrases we use to describe everyday things can change.  Even though we’re both speaking English, etymology can vary widely, and the same item or activity might leave you scratching your head when you hear it coming from someone on the other side of the […]

item.title: What we know about the Rolling Stones’ “Hackney Diamonds”

item.description:
Yep, it’s official. The Rolling Stones are coming out with a new album next month. And after a few weeks of teases and websites that barely worked, they officially announced it in a livestream with Jimmy Fallon. And in spite of its relatively short length, we learned quite a bit. Case in point, the name […]

item.title: Ten Interesting Facts about King James II
item.dc:creator: John Rabon
item.description:
